subs.text: Of the 5 (of ~100 who took the exam) students to give “free text comments” on our astrophysics course this year, one was very positive, two were equivocal, one complained about our email response times, and one was “delete this module”.

There is a scary & common misconception in physics that students work better if… supervisors & … senior group members pressure them with negative, condescending language. —Physics World, July ‘22. Print only? WTF. Does anyone really believe this? [link]

subs.text: I ordered a Mac Studio Display through an Apple Educational reseller in the UK around 1 April. It hasn’t arrived yet. Has anyone had any similar (or otherwise) experience of such lengthy delays (~16 weeks)?
subs.rawText: I ordered a Mac Studio Display through an Apple Educational reseller in the UK around 1 April. It hasn’t arrived yet. Has anyone had any similar (or otherwise) experience of such lengthy delays (~16 weeks)?

subs.text: @FiveThirtyEight Aren’t the recession poll results *entirely* due to respondents conflating “recession” with “bad economy” in general, and inflation being a very clear sign of a bad economy?
subs.rawText: @FiveThirtyEight Aren’t the recession poll results *entirely* due to respondents conflating “recession” with “bad economy” in general, and inflation being a very clear sign of a bad economy?

subs.text: July 20

If the ROI from programs like this is so good, why not make businesses pay for it themselves instead of funnelling more money to private industry (and let gov’t invest in more blue-skies research instead)? Yes, I know, I am biased, and it's not zero-sum. [link]
subs.rawText:
If the ROI from programs like this is so good, why not make businesses pay for it themselves instead of funnelling more money to private industry (and let gov’t invest in more blue-skies research instead)?

Yes, I know, I am biased, and it's not zero-sum. https://t.co/hciJVlrVEO

subs.text: July 19

“For generations, homes in Britain were designed to retain heat, to make cold winters bearable.” Clearly this person has never lived in Britain, where we spend the winters wearing extra jumpers to keep warm in our inadequately-heated and -insulated homes. [link]

subs.text: July 2

@skdh @WKCosmo The decoherence-is-enough response would be that it is converted into a classically indeterminate state — I.e., it really is up or down, you just don’t know which.  (nb. I don’t really buy this and may be mischaracterising it.)
subs.rawText: @skdh @WKCosmo The decoherence-is-enough response would be that it is converted into a classically indeterminate state — I.e., it really is up or down, you just don’t know which.  (nb. I don’t really buy this and may be mischaracterising it.)

subs.text: @skdh @WKCosmo I guess you then need an epistemic/Bayesian updating step to non-mysteriously convert (not “collapse”) your description of the state to the actual observed case.
subs.rawText: @skdh @WKCosmo I guess you then need an epistemic/Bayesian updating step to non-mysteriously convert (not “collapse”) your description of the state to the actual observed case.

subs.text: @WKCosmo @skdh “Everything is quantum mechanical, all of the time” is a good slogan, but what does it mean? Decoherence drives systems to near classicality, but off-diagonal terms in the density matrix are still non-zero.
subs.rawText: @WKCosmo @skdh “Everything is quantum mechanical, all of the time” is a good slogan, but what does it mean? Decoherence drives systems to near classicality, but off-diagonal terms in the density matrix are still non-zero.

subs.text: @WKCosmo @skdh But they aren’t zero, so why isn’t the burden on you to show why that has no observational consequences? Or you have just re-invented many-worlds branches.
subs.rawText: @WKCosmo @skdh But they aren’t zero, so why isn’t the burden on you to show why that has no observational consequences? Or you have just re-invented many-worlds branches.

subs.text: @WKCosmo @skdh What’s “it”? What is the prediction?
subs.rawText: @WKCosmo @skdh What’s “it”? What is the prediction?
